title: Okataina Volcanic Centre

meta_description: Okataina is a massive rhyolitic volcanic centre in New Zealand's Taupo Volcanic Zone. Home to Mount Tarawera and the 1886 eruption. Full history and facts.

quick_answer.what: The Okataina Volcanic Centre (OVC) is a massive, dominantly rhyolitic volcanic complex in New Zealand's Taupo Volcanic Zone, encompassing the Haroharo and Tarawera dome complexes within a 16 × 26 km caldera.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 1981 (hydrothermal, Waimangu). The catastrophic 1886 Mount Tarawera eruption killed over 100 people and destroyed the world-famous Pink and White Terraces.
quick_answer.famous_for: The 1886 Tarawera eruption, the Pink and White Terraces, and five VEI 5 eruptions over the past 10,000 years.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — capable of producing VEI 5+ explosive eruptions. The city of Rotorua (population ~75,000) lies on the caldera margin.

overview.content: The Okataina Volcanic Centre (OVC) is one of the most explosively active volcanic complexes in New Zealand and one of the most productive rhyolitic centres on Earth. Located in the central Taupo Volcanic Zone (TVZ) of the North Island, the OVC encompasses a 16 × 26 km caldera surrounded by extensive ignimbrite sheets from multiple caldera-forming eruptions. Two major dome complexes occupy the caldera interior: the Haroharo complex in the north, consisting of rhyolitic lava domes up to 1,111 m elevation, and the Tarawera complex in the south, famous for the catastrophic 1886 eruption that killed over 100 people and destroyed the world-renowned Pink and White Terraces. The OVC has produced five VEI 5 eruptions in the past 10,000 years — an eruption rate that makes it one of the most active rhyolitic systems globally. The city of Rotorua (population ~75,000) lies on the western margin of the caldera, and the surrounding region's economy depends heavily on geothermal tourism centered on the OVC's hydrothermal features at Waimangu, Wai-O-Tapu, and other thermal areas.

geology_and_formation.content: The OVC lies within the Taupo Volcanic Zone, an active extensional rift zone generated by the oblique subduction of the Pacific Plate beneath the Australian Plate. The TVZ is one of the most volcanically productive regions on Earth, and the OVC is its second-largest rhyolitic centre after the Taupo caldera. The Haroharo caldera formed incrementally through multiple collapse events between approximately 300,000 and 50,000 years ago. The dominantly rhyolitic magma — highly silica-rich, viscous, and gas-charged — produces characteristically explosive eruptions. The Haroharo complex in the northern OVC consists of numerous rhyolitic lava domes. The Tarawera complex comprises 11 rhyolitic lava domes, the oldest formed about 15,000 years ago and the youngest during the Kaharoa eruption approximately 1310 CE. The caldera system has impounded several lakes — Rotoiti, Rotoehu, Okataina, and Tarawera — against its outer margins. A major hydrothermal area at Waimangu was created by the 1886 eruption.

eruption_history_overview.content: The OVC has produced 31 recorded eruptions spanning from approximately 8050 BCE to 1981 CE. Five of these reached VEI 5 — a remarkable frequency for a rhyolitic system. Major explosive episodes occurred around 7560 BCE, 6060 BCE, and 3580 BCE from the Haroharo complex, and in 1310 CE (Kaharoa eruption) and 1886 CE from the Tarawera complex. Post-1886 activity has been limited to hydrothermal eruptions from Waimangu and nearby thermal areas through 1981.

subsections.title: The 1310 CE Kaharoa Eruption — VEI 5
subsections.content: The Kaharoa eruption around 1310 CE was the most recent major rhyolitic eruption from the Tarawera complex, rated VEI 5. It produced the youngest lava domes in the Tarawera chain and deposited widespread pyroclastic material across the central North Island. The Kaharoa tephra layer is used as a chronological marker because it closely predates the arrival of Māori settlers in New Zealand, providing a geological timestamp for human colonization of the islands.

subsections.title: The 1886 Mount Tarawera Eruption — Destruction of the Pink and White Terraces
subsections.content: The June 10, 1886 eruption of Mount Tarawera is the most famous volcanic event in New Zealand's colonial history. A series of explosive vents opened along a 17 km fissure, producing a VEI 5 basaltic explosive eruption — unusual for this rhyolite-dominated system. At least 108 people were killed, including residents of the Māori villages of Te Wairoa, Moura, and Te Ariki. The world-famous Pink and White Terraces — massive siliceous sinter formations on the shores of Lake Rotomahana, considered one of the 19th century's great natural wonders — were completely destroyed. The eruption excavated the Rotomahana explosion crater and created the Waimangu geothermal valley.

subsections.title: Post-1886 Hydrothermal Activity at Waimangu
subsections.content: Following 1886, the Waimangu thermal area hosted the world's largest geyser — the Waimangu Geyser (1900–1904), with eruptions reaching up to 460 m height. Hydrothermal eruptions from Echo Crater and other features continued intermittently through 1981, demonstrating ongoing thermal activity. These events, while individually small (VEI 1), confirm the volcanic system remains active at depth.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: The OVC is monitored by GeoNet, operated by GNS Science. The monitoring network includes seismometers, GPS stations, lake-level gauges, and geochemical sampling. The volcanic alert level is currently at 0. However, the OVC's history demonstrates that rhyolitic systems can reawaken with relatively little precursory time. Hydrothermal features remain active, and Lake Rotomahana and the Waimangu area show elevated temperatures and gas emissions. GNS Science considers the OVC one of New Zealand's highest-risk volcanic systems.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: The OVC poses severe hazards due to its demonstrated capacity for large explosive rhyolitic eruptions. A VEI 5 eruption — which has occurred five times in 10,000 years — would generate extensive pyroclastic flows, heavy ashfall across the central North Island, and potential lake-breach lahars. Rotorua (~75,000 people) on the western caldera margin would be directly affected. Even a smaller eruption comparable to the 1886 basaltic event would cause significant destruction and potentially displace tens of thousands, devastating the regional tourism economy.

geography_and_physical_description.content: The OVC occupies a broad area of the central TVZ, characterized by rhyolitic lava domes, lakes, and thermal areas. The Haroharo complex reaches 1,111 m, while the Tarawera complex is dominated by the dramatic rift from the 1886 eruption. Lakes Tarawera, Okataina, Rotoiti, and Rotoehu occupy depressions between dome complexes and the caldera rim. The Waimangu thermal valley features boiling springs, steaming cliffs, and the vivid Inferno Crater lake.

cultural_significance.content: The Okataina region holds profound significance for Te Arawa Māori. The 1886 eruption devastated several Māori communities, and the destruction of the Pink and White Terraces (Te Otukapuarangi and Te Tarata) was a cultural loss of incalculable significance. The buried village of Te Wairoa is now a museum and memorial. The Kaharoa tephra from ~1310 CE serves as a crucial archaeological marker for earliest Māori settlement, linking volcanic history to cultural origins.

nearby_volcanoes.content: The OVC lies within the Taupo Volcanic Zone alongside several other major volcanic centres. The Taupo caldera, responsible for one of the largest eruptions in human history (the 232 CE VEI 7 event), lies approximately 80 km to the south. Ruapehu and Tongariro, New Zealand's most recently active andesitic stratovolcanoes, rise in the southern TVZ. Whakaari/White Island, an active submarine-to-island volcano, lies offshore in the Bay of Plenty. Together, these systems make New Zealand one of the most volcanically active countries in the world.

facts: The OVC has produced five VEI 5 eruptions in the past 10,000 years — one of the highest rates of large explosive eruptions for any rhyolitic system on Earth.
The 1886 Tarawera eruption destroyed the Pink and White Terraces, considered among the greatest natural wonders of the 19th-century world.
The Waimangu Geyser (1900–1904) was the largest geyser ever recorded, with eruption columns reaching up to 460 m (1,500 ft).
The Kaharoa tephra layer (~1310 CE) serves as a key chronological marker for the earliest Māori settlement of New Zealand.
The 1886 eruption was basaltic — unusual for this dominantly rhyolitic system — opening a 17 km fissure across Mount Tarawera.
At least 108 people were killed in the 1886 eruption, including residents of the Māori villages of Te Wairoa, Moura, and Te Ariki.
Rotorua, a city of approximately 75,000 people, sits on the western margin of the Okataina caldera.
The Haroharo caldera formed incrementally between approximately 300,000 and 50,000 years ago through multiple collapse events.
The OVC's rhyolitic magma is among the most silica-rich and explosive volcanic material on Earth.
Lake Tarawera, impounded against the caldera margin, lies directly adjacent to the 1886 rift and remains a focus of monitoring for future volcanic unrest.

faqs.question: Is Okataina still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, the Okataina Volcanic Centre is classified as active. Its most recent eruption was a hydrothermal event at Waimangu in 1981, and the last major magmatic eruption was the 1886 Mount Tarawera event. The system's hydrothermal areas remain vigorous, and five VEI 5 eruptions in the past 10,000 years demonstrate that the volcanic system is capable of significant future activity. GeoNet monitors the complex continuously.

faqs.question: What happened in the 1886 Tarawera eruption?
faqs.answer: On June 10, 1886, a 17 km fissure opened across Mount Tarawera, producing a VEI 5 basaltic explosive eruption. At least 108 people were killed, several Māori villages were buried, and the world-famous Pink and White Terraces — massive siliceous sinter formations on Lake Rotomahana — were completely destroyed. The eruption created the Waimangu thermal valley and fundamentally changed the regional landscape. It remains New Zealand's deadliest volcanic disaster in the colonial era.

faqs.question: What were the Pink and White Terraces?
faqs.answer: The Pink and White Terraces (Te Otukapuarangi and Te Tarata in Māori) were enormous siliceous sinter formations on the shores of Lake Rotomahana, created by mineral-rich hot springs depositing silica over thousands of years. They were considered one of the world's greatest natural wonders and attracted tourists from around the globe in the 19th century. The 1886 Tarawera eruption completely destroyed them. Submerged remnants were rediscovered in Lake Rotomahana in 2011.

faqs.question: Could Okataina produce another large eruption?
faqs.answer: Yes. The OVC has produced five VEI 5 eruptions in the past 10,000 years, averaging one approximately every 2,000 years — though the intervals are irregular. A future VEI 5 eruption would produce widespread pyroclastic flows, heavy ashfall across the central North Island, and potential lahars. Rotorua and surrounding communities would be severely affected. While no eruption is currently imminent, GNS Science considers the OVC one of New Zealand's highest-priority volcanic hazards.

faqs.question: Can you visit the Okataina volcanic area?
faqs.answer: Yes, the Okataina region is one of New Zealand's premier tourist destinations. The Waimangu Volcanic Valley, created by the 1886 eruption, offers guided walks past boiling lakes and steaming craters. The buried village of Te Wairoa is an open-air museum. Lake Tarawera offers boating, fishing, and swimming. The broader Rotorua geothermal area includes Wai-O-Tapu Thermal Wonderland and numerous hot spring resorts. Mount Tarawera itself can be visited by guided tour.

faqs.question: How far is Okataina from Rotorua?
faqs.answer: The western margin of the Okataina caldera lies approximately 15 km east of Rotorua city centre. Lake Tarawera, within the volcanic complex, is about 24 km southeast of Rotorua and is a popular day trip destination. The Waimangu Volcanic Valley is approximately 20 km south of Rotorua. Rotorua (population ~75,000) serves as the main gateway for visiting the OVC's volcanic and geothermal attractions.
